x_symbol.description: Returns an array of elements which are descendants of parentEle and have tagName and clsName. If parentEle is null or not present, document will be used. If tagName is null or not present, "*" will be used.

par.name: sClsName
par.note: String. A className. This can also be a regular expression.

par.name: oParentEle
par.note: Element reference. If omitted "document" will be used. This can be an ID string if this function uses xGetElementsByTagName.

par.name: sTagName
par.note: String. An HTML tagName. If omitted "*" will be used.

par.name: fnCallback
par.note: Callback function, iterates thru the list of found elements. Is passed a reference to each Element object found.

x_symbol.return: Always returns an array but it may have zero length.

comment.author: mf
mf
comment.note: If you don't need IE4 support and don't ever pass a '*' for tagName then you can use "p.getElementsByTagName(t)" instead of "xGetElementsByTagName(t, p)". It will then be up to you to take the precautions normally taken by xGetElementsByTagName, for example: p=p||document, t=t||'*', and handling the IE5 '*' bug.
